### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 47 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: During Dostoyevsky's time there were two significant and opposing directions in Russian literary criticism. One position maintained that art stood high above the present and the everyday, while the radical view maintained that art had a right to exist only if it found its sources in concrete reality, and, through the exposure of want and injustice, it contributed to the creation of a new society; literature, in other words, should be useful. Dostoyevsky took a third position. As a realist, he never doubted that reality was literature's crucial source. But his understanding of reality went deeper than the one prevailing among radical critics, since for Dostoyevsky there was no distinction in principle between fantasy and reality, and reality was far more than the merely tangible. The radical critics' demand that reality be depicted "as it is" was meaningless for Dostoyevsky; reality was necessarily shaped by the person who experienced it: what may not be reality for you may be reality for me. The task of the writer was to explode the boundaries of the so-called real world. Within perceptible "reality" exists another sphere, the fantastic, which is not in any way superfluous to a writer's concerns: "The fantastic must be so intimately bound up with the real that one almost believes in it." The radical critics' insistence that art must serve a particular political view was for Dostoyevsky the equivalent of assigning to art "a shameful destiny." A literary work must stand or fall on its "artistic merit," he explained. The utilitarian claim that the formal aspects of a work were of secondary importance so long as its goal was good and its purpose clear struck Dostoyevsky as a contradiction in terms. Only fully realized artistic works could fulfill their goals. But what does it mean to say that a work is "artistic" ? Dostoyevsky defined it thus: "To say that a novelist is 'artistic'means that he possesses a talent to express his thoughts in characters and images so that when the reader has finished the novel, he has fully understood the author's thoughts. Therefore, artistry is quite simply the ability to write well." The radical critics' requirement that art must at all costs be "useful" to people and society seemed to Dostoyevsky unsatisfactory. How can we know what will show itself to be useful? Can we say with assurance how useful the Iliad has been to humankind? No, Dostoyevsky believed, when it comes to this we encounter breadths that cannot be measured with any precision; sometimes a work of art may appear to deviate from reality and serve no useful purpose because we cannot see clearly what paths it may take to become useful.
Question: According to the passage, Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' view of realism in literature because he believed
Choices:
  A: reality is not independent of the experiences of individuals
  B: realism is unequal to the task of representing political views
  C: art should be elevated above the portrayal of reality
  D: realism does not in fact facilitate the exposure of social inequities or contribute to the creation of a new society
  E: reality is not the crucial source of successful literature
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Dostoyevsky believed that reality was literature's crucial source.
  He did not agree with the radical critics' view of realism in literature.
  The radical critics demanded that reality be depicted "as it is," and that it should contribute to the creation of a new society.
  Dostoyevsky believed that reality was not separate from the experiences of individuals, and that there was no distinction in principle between fantasy and reality.
Thought: 
  Dostoyevsky did not agree with the radical critics' view of realism because he believed that reality was not independent of the experiences of individuals and there was no distinction in principle between fantasy and reality.
  He did not agree with the radical critics' demand for art to serve a particular political view.
  Dostoyevsky believed that literature had a deeper understanding of reality, and that art should not be used only for political purposes; it should stand or fall on its artistic merit.
  Therefore, he believed that reality was the crucial source of successful literature.
  The correct answer is A: reality is not independent of the experiences of individuals.
Criticism: 
  Your thought process is correct and you have identified Dostoyevsky's disagreement with the radical critics' view of realism.
  However, you did not mention the other options, such as B, C, D, and E, so it is not clear if they are incorrect.
Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  Dostoyevsky believed that reality was literature's crucial source.
  Dostoyevsky's understanding of reality went deeper than the one prevailing among radical critics.
  Reality was necessarily shaped by the person who experienced it; what may not be reality for you may be reality for me.
Thought: 
  Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' that art should have a strict relation to reality.
  He believed that reality was shaped by personal experience and that there is no distinction between fantasy and reality.
  The radical critics' demand that reality be depicted "as it is" was meaningless for Dostoyevsky.
  The task of the writer was to explode the boundaries of the so-called real world. Within perceptible "reality" exists another sphere, the fantastic which is not in any way superfluous to a writer's concerns.
  Dostoyevsky's definition of artist laid on the ability to write well and fully express thoughts in characters and images.
  Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' claim that art must be useful and in service of a political view.
  A literary work must stand or fall on its "artistic merit."
  Only fully realized artistic works could fulfill their goals.
Criticism: 
  You are correct that Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' view of realism in literature.
  However, it was specifically because he believed that reality was shaped by personal experience and there is no distinction between fantasy and reality.
  Dostoevsky believed that art should neither be elevated above nor reduced beneath the portrayal of reality.
  Therefore, options B, C, and E are wrong.
  Option D is also wrong because the passage does not mention that Dostoevsky believed that realism does not in fact facilitate the exposure of social inequities or contribute to the creation of a new society. 
Action: Answer("A")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  During Dostoyevsky's time there were two significant and opposing directions in Russian literary criticism.
  One position maintained that art stood high above the present and the everyday, while the radical view maintained that art had a right to exist only if it found its sources in concrete reality, and, through the exposure of want and injustice, it contributed to the creation of a new society; literature, in other words, should be useful. 
  Dostoyevsky took a third position. As a realist, he never doubted that reality was literature's crucial source. 
  But his understanding of reality went deeper than the one prevailing among radical critics, since for Dostoyevsky there was no distinction in principle between fantasy and reality, and reality was far more than the merely tangible. 
  The radical critics' demand that reality be depicted "as it is" was meaningless for Dostoyevsky; reality was necessarily shaped by the person who experienced it: what may not be reality for you may be reality for me. 
  The task of the writer was to explode the boundaries of the so-called real world. Within perceptible "reality" exists another sphere, the fantastic, which is not in any way superfluous to a writer's concerns. 
  The radical critics' insistence that art must serve a particular political view was for Dostoyevsky the equivalent of assigning to art "a shameful destiny." 
  A literary work must stand or fall on its "artistic merit." The utilitarian claim that the formal aspects of a work were of secondary importance so long as its goal was good and its purpose clear struck Dostoyevsky as a contradiction in terms. Only fully realized artistic works could fulfill their goals. 
  Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' requirement that art must at all costs be "useful" to people and society. 

Thought:
  The correct answer is the one that correctly captures why Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' view of realism in literature.
  Dostoyevsky disagreed because he believed that reality, though a crucial source, was far more than tangible experiences; it also included a sphere that exists within perceptible reality, that is, the fantastic. 
  Dostoyevsky believed that the task of the writer was less about depicting reality as it exists in order to expose social inequalities, and more about exploding the boundaries of the so-called real world.
  Furthermore, Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' view that art must serve a particular political view, as he believed that a literary work must stand or fall on its artistic merit. 
  Overall, Dostoevsky's disagreement with these critics was fundamentally about his belief that literature was an art form and should therefore not be constrained by the views of its critics.

Evaluation:
  The options presented all pertain to Dostoyevsky's disagreement with the radical critics' view of realism.
  A is something Dostoyevsky believed, but it does not capture his disagreement with the radical critics' view of realism.
  B is not something Dostoyevsky believed; he disagreed with a requirement that art must serve a particular political view, not that realism is unequal to the task of representing political views.
  C is not something Dostoyevsky believed; he disagreed with the view that art should be elevated above the portrayal of reality. 
  D is not something Dostoyevsky believed; he did not oppose the exposure of social inequities or the creation of a new society. Rather, he believed that the task of the writer was less about depicting reality as it exists.
  E is partially true, but it does not capture Dostoyevsky's essential disagreement with the radical critics' view of realism. 

Answer: Answer("A")
Response 3:
Knowledge:
  1. According to the passage, during Dostoyevsky's time, there was a debate between two significant and opposing directions in Russian literary criticism— one position which maintained that art stood high above the present and the everyday, while the radical view maintained that art had a right to exist only if it found its sources in concrete reality, and, through the exposure of want and injustice, it contributed to the creation of a new society.
  2. Dostoyevsky took a third position. He was a realist who had a deeper understanding of reality than radical critics and believed that there was no distinction between fantasy and reality. Therefore, the task of the writer was to explode the boundaries of the so-called real world.
  3. Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' requirement that art must at all costs be "useful" to people and society because he believed sometimes a work of art may appear to deviate from reality and serve no useful purpose because we cannot see clearly what paths it may take to become useful.
  4. Dostoyevsky believed that the utilitarian claim that the formal aspects of a work were of secondary importance so long as its goal was good and its purpose clear struck him as a contradiction in terms since only fully realized artistic works could fulfill their goals.
Thought:
  1. Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' view of realism in literature.
  2. The radical critics' view maintained that art had a right to exist only if it contributed to the creation of a new society.
  3. Dostoyevsky believed that a work of art should stand or fall on its artistic merit and that a literary work must be fully realized to fulfill its goals.
  4. Dostoyevsky disagreed with the radical critics' requirement that art must at all costs be "useful" to people and society.
  5. Therefore, Dostoevsky disagreed with the radical critics' practical and utilitarian purpose of realism.
  6. The correct answer is D: realism does not in fact facilitate the exposure of social inequities or contribute to the creation of a new society.
Criticism:
  The passage does not directly suggest that Dostoyevsky disagreed with the social purpose of radical critics, but he believed that realism should be handled as a unique aspect of human experience and should explode the boundaries of the real world. So, answer choice A could be another possible answer. Answer C is not clearly suggested in the passage. Answer B does not accurately reflect Dostoyevsky's view. Answer E does not accurately reflect the contents of the passage.

  The text explains that there were two competing views of realism in Russian literary criticism during Dostoyevsky's time. 
  One view maintained that art should be elevated above the tangible world, while the other insisted that art should serve political and social reform. 
  Dostoyevsky took a third position, believing that reality -- including both tangible and intangible experiences -- was crucial for fiction but should not be constrained by any particular political, moral, or artistic agenda.
Thought:
  The question asks what Dostoyevsky's view of realism in literature was 
  The text explains that Dostoyevsky believed that reality was the crucial source of fiction but that reality was not limited to the tangible, visible world. 
  Dostoyevsky believed that the constraints of radical critics' demands -- that literature should be politically useful and portray reality "as it is" -- limited the imagination and creativity of writers.
  Therefore, Dostoevsky disagreed with radical critics' view of realism in literature since he believed that reality could not be sharply delimited, and that art and the fantastic were intertwined with reality in crucial ways.
  So, the answer is A: reality is not independent of the experiences of individuals.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 48 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Hundreds of clay tablets marked in cuneiform have been found in excavations of the Sumerian city of Uruk (in present-day Iraq). Though the tablets date from roughly 3000 B.C., the writing on them uses relatively few pictographs; instead, numerous abstract symbols are used. The sign for "sheep," for example, is not an image of a sheep, but rather a circled cross, while the sign for "metal" is a crescent with five lines. Because of its early date, this seemingly sudden appearance of such abstract writing has long puzzled researchers. At the same time, among prepottery clay artifacts found at archaeological sites along the Jordan and nearby rivers are thousands of small, hand-modeled tokens of fired clay, some dating to before 4000 B.C. Often ignored by archaeologists-some concluded without evidence that they were amulets or game pieces-the tokens are identified by Denise Schmandt-Besserat in her book Before Writing (1992) as overlooked predecessors to the written word. The earliest of the tokens were simple in form-small cones, spheres, and pyramids-and they were often inscribed. In 1966, a hollow tablet containing several of these tokens was discovered, and more than 100 additional tablets, which are now recognized as sealed envelopes of clay, have since been found. Later envelopes are also inscribed with impressions of tokens in the outer clay, signaling exactly what each envelope contained. Noting that these inscriptions are clearly traceable to later, known inscriptions of farm products, Schmandt-Besserat theorizes that the envelopes contained official records of villagers' contributions to temple-based grain and livestock pools. After 4000 B.C., hundreds of new token forms developed, as a rise in industry boosted the token system. Many forms are figurative, such as bowls or jars with handles, suggesting that villagers' crafts were becoming more diversified and sophisticated. The token system, essentially a system of three-dimensional nouns, was replaced in about 3 1 00 B.C.by a system of marks on clay tablets. A few centuries later, this latter system was to display the first use of numerals, where simple marks coded the concepts of one, two, and so forth. The eventual evolution of this system into mature writing, Schmandt-Besserat suggests, can be seen in the following example: At first it took two ovoid tokens to record two jars of oil. A little later, it took two markings on a clay tablet to achieve this-one mark, using the outline of the old token, to record the customary unit measure for oil, the jarful, and a second mark to convey the numeral: two oil jars. Eventually, it took three signs on the tablet, one for the numeral 2, one for the standard jarful, and a new symbol that denoted oil itself. With three such signs, an abstract and flexible written form had arrived.
Question: The passage stat es that the writing on clay tablets found in Uruk
Choices:
  A: was not deciphered by archaeologists until 1992
  B: used relatively few pictographic symbols
  C: eventually evolved into a more abstract and flexible linguistic system
  D: transcribed a language that was commonly spoken along the Jordan and nearby rivers
  E: transcribed a language that was much older than archaeologists would have expected
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses the discovery of ancient clay tablets in Uruk, which date back to roughly 3000 B.C. 
  The writing on the tablets uses abstract symbols rather than pictographs.
  Preceding the development of writing on clay tablets were small, hand-modeled tokens of fired clay.
Thought: 
  The writing on the clay tablets found in Uruk and discussed in the passage used relatively few pictographic symbols and instead primarily used abstract symbols.
  According to the passage, the token system that preceded the writing on clay tablets was essentially a system of three-dimensional nouns.
  Eventually, this token system evolved into a more abstract and flexible linguistic system, with 'numerical' signs for quantities and symbols to denote the objects being valued growing more abstract and less representational.
  Therefore, the only option that accurately describes and agrees with this information from the passage is C: eventually evolved into a more abstract and flexible linguistic system.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("C")

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 49 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Passage A Karl Popper's main contribution to the philosophy of science science concerns the power of negative evidence. The fundamental point is simple: No number of white swans, for example, can ever prove that all swans are white, but a single black swan disproves the hypothesis. Popper gives this logical asymmetry between positive and negative evidence hyperbolic application, maintaining that positive evidence has no value as evidence and that negative evidence is tantamount to disproof. Moreover, Popper takes the search for negative evidence to be at the heart of scientific research; that is, for Popper, scientific research involves not only generating bold theories, but also searching for evidence that would disprove them. Indeed, for him, a theory counts as scientific only if it makes predictions that are testable in this way. However, Popper's use of the logical asymmetry does not adequately capture the actual situation scientists face. If a theory deductively entails a false prediction, then the theory must be false as well. But a scientific theory rarely entails predictions on its own. When scientists actually derive a theory's predictions, they almost always need diverse additional "auxiliary" premises, which appeal to other theories, to the correct functioning of instrumentation, to the absence of disturbing forces, etc. When a prediction fails, logic indicates that at least one of the premises must be false, but it does not indicate which one. When an experiment does not work out as predicted, there is usually more than one possible explanation. Positive evidence is never conclusive. But negative evidence rarely is either. Passage B When the planet Uranus was discovered, astronomers attempted to predict its orbit. They based their predictions on Newton's laws and auxiliary assumptions about the mass of the sun and the masses, orbits, and velocities of other planets. One of the auxiliary assumptions was that no planets existed in the vicinity of Uranus. When the astronomers made their observations, they found that the orbit they had predicted for Uranus was incorrect. One possible explanation for the failure of their prediction was that Newton's laws were incorrect. Another was that there was an error in the auxiliary assumptions. The astronomers changed their assumptions about the existence of other planets, concluding that there must be another planet close enough to Uranus to produce the observed orbit. Not long afterward, scientists discovered the planet Neptune in the precise place it would have to be to bring their calculations into alignment with their observations Later astronomers, again using Newton's laws, predicted the orbit of Mercury. Once again, the predictions were not borne out. They hypothesized the existence of another planet in the vicinity, which they called Vulcan. However, Vulcan was never found, and some scientists began to think that perhaps Newton's laws were in error. Finally, when Einstein's general theory of relativity was introduced, astronomers discovered that calculations based on that theory and the old auxiliary assumptions predicted the observed orbit of Mercury, leading to the rejection of Newton's theory of gravity and to increased confidence in Einstein's theory.
Question: Which one of the following is mentioned in passage A and illustrated in passage B?
Choices:
  A: repudiating an experimental result
  B: revising a theory
  C: disproving a theory
  D: predicting a planet's orbit
  E: theories that are not testable by experiment
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Passage A discusses Karl Popper's ideas about the role of negative evidence in scientific research.
  Passage B gives examples of astronomers revising their theories based on new observations and auxiliary assumptions.
Thought: 
  Passage A emphasizes that scientific research involves not only generating bold theories but also searching for evidence that would disprove them.
  Passage B describes how astronomers revised their predictions of the orbits of two planets, Uranus and Mercury, when their initial predictions were not borne out. 
  The revising of predictions involves altering the theory that underlies the prediction. 
  Therefore, revising a theory is the best answer.
  Answer: B: revising a theory.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 1:

  Passage A discusses Karl Popper's views on the power of negative evidence and provides criticism on it. 
  Passage B presents the historical illustrations of predictions of Uranus's orbit and Mercury's orbit, which were made based on auxiliary assumptions in Newton's laws and revised accordingly, leading to a new theory of relativity.
Thought: 
  According to Passage B:
  Uranus's orbit and Mercury's orbit were predicted based on Newton's laws and auxiliary premises.
  Since predictions for the Uranus's orbit of Uranus were incorrect, scientists changed auxiliary assumptions about the existence of planets, which led to the discovery of Neptune. 
  Similarly, predictions for Mercury's orbit were incorrect, and scientists hypothesized the existence of another planet called Vulcan; but later, with Einstein's general theory of relativity, the calculations matched the observations, leading to the rejection of Newton's theory of gravity and increased confidence in Einstein's theory.
  In both cases, scientists revised their theories based on new evidence and observations.
  Therefore, revising a theory is mentioned in passage A and illustrated in passage B.
The answer is B: revising a theory.
Criticism: None.

  Passage B illustrates an example of how astronomers predicted the orbit of Uranus based on Newton's laws and auxiliary assumptions, but their predictions were incorrect. They revised their assumption about the existence of other planets and hypothesized the existence of another planet in the vicinity, which explains the orbit of Uranus. Later, they predicted the orbit of Mercury, but their predictions were incorrect again. They hypothesized the existence of another planet in the vicinity, called Vulcan, but it was never found. Finally, Einstein's general theory of relativity was introduced, and calculations based on that theory and the old auxiliary assumptions predicted the observed orbit of Mercury.

  Passage A talks about searching for negative evidence and revising theories.
  Passage B illustrates how astronomers revised their assumptions about the existence of other planets when their predictions about Uranus's orbit were incorrect. They also hypothesized the existence of another planet called Vulcan to explain the orbit of Mercury, but later discovered that Einstein's theory of relativity explained the orbit of Mercury and rejected Newton's theory of gravity. 
  Therefore, the answer is B: revising a theory.
Criticism:

  Passage A discusses the power of negative evidence and the concept of testability in scientific research.
  Passage B gives examples of astronomers using theories and auxiliary assumptions to predict the orbits of planets and revising their assumptions when predictions were not borne out.

  Passage B: The astronomers first predicted the orbit of Uranus based on Newton's laws and auxiliary assumptions. Later, they predicted the orbit of Mercury based on Newton's laws, hypothesizing the existence of another planet to explain the observations; however, the planet was never found, putting Newton's laws into question until Einstein's general theory of relativity explained the observations.

  The answer is B: revising a theory.

  Passage B provides examples of astronomers attempting to predict the orbit of planets and revising their theory based on updated auxiliary assumptions.

  Passage B provides specific examples of astronomers revising their theory based on updated auxiliary assumptions, indicating a possible relationship with Popper's ideas.
  Of the options, "revising a theory" accurately captures the astronomers' actions in Passage B and is also in line with Popper's ideas about searching for negative evidence.

Response 7:
Knowledge: 
  Passage A is about Karl Popper's contribution to the philosophy of science. He maintains that positive evidence has no value as evidence and that negative evidence is tantamount to disproof. He takes the search for negative evidence to be at the heart of scientific research; that is, for Popper, scientific research involves not only generating bold theories, but also searching for evidence that would disprove them.
  Passage B talks about the discovery of Uranus and how scientists predicted its orbit using Newton's laws and auxiliary assumptions. They found that their prediction was incorrect and hypothesized the existence of another planet, which they later discovered to be Neptune. This scenario is similar to what happened when scientists predicted the orbit of Mercury using Newton's laws and hypothesized the existence of a planet named Vulcan. However, Vulcan was never found, and Einstein's general theory of relativity was introduced to predict Mercury's orbit accurately.
Thought: 
  There is mention of generating and checking theories that would disprove them in passage A. 
  In passage B, scientists had to revise an auxiliary assumption to predict Uranus's orbit correctly after they had made an incorrect prediction. 
  Later on, scientists had to revise Newton's laws and hypothesize another planet's existence to predict Mercury's orbit accurately.
  Therefore, the answer is B: Revising a theory.

  None.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 50 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: In a recent study, Mario Garcia argues that in the United States between 1930 and I960 the group of political activists he calls the "Mexican American Generation" was more radical and politically diverse than earlier historians have recognized. Through analysis of the work of some of the era's most important scholars, Garcia does provide persuasive evidence that in the 1930s and 1940s these activists anticipated many of the reforms proposed by the more militant Chicanos of the 1960s and 1970s. His study, however, suffers from two flaws.First, Garcia's analysis of the evidence he provides to demonstrate the Mexican American Generation's political diversity is not entirely consistent. Indeed, he undermines his primary thesis by emphasizing an underlying consensus among various groups that tends to conceal the full significance of their differences. Groups such as the League of United Latin American Citizens, an organization that encouraged Mexican Americans to pursue a civil rights strategy of assimilation into the United States political and cultural mainstream, were often diametrically opposed to organizations such as the Congress of Spanish-Speaking People, a coalition group that advocated bilingual education and equal rights for resident aliens in the United States. Garcia acknowledges these differences but dismisses them as insignificant, given that the goals of groups as disparate as these centered on liberal reform, not revolution. But one need only note the fierce controversies that occurred during the period over United States immigration policies and the question of assimilation versus cultural maintenance to recognize that Mexican American political history since 1930 has been characterized not by consensus but by intense and lively debate.Second, Garcia may be exaggerating the degree to which the views of these activists were representative of the ethnic Mexican population residing in the United States during this period. Noting that by 1930 the proportion of the Mexican American population that had been born in the United States had significantly increased, Garcia argues that between 1930 and 1960 a new generation of Mexican American leaders appeared, one that was more acculturated and hence more politically active than its predecessor. Influenced by their experience of discrimination and by the inclusive rhetoric of World War II slogans, these leaders, according to Garcia, were determined to achieve full civil rights for all United States residents of Mexican descent. However, it is not clear how far this outlook extended beyond these activists. Without a better understanding of the political implications of important variables such as patterns of and rates of Mexican immigration and naturalization, and the variations in ethnic consciousness these variables help to create, one cannot assume that an increase in the proportion of Mexican Americans born in the United States necessarily resulted in an increase in the ethnic Mexican population's political activism.
Question: The passage supports which one of the following statements about ethnic consciousness among Mexican Americans?
Choices:
  A: Ethnic consciousness increases when rates of Mexican immigration and naturalization increase.
  B: Ethnic consciousness increases when the number of Mexican Americans born in the United States increases.
  C: Ethnic consciousness decreases when the number of Mexican Americans assimilating into the culture of the United States increases.
  D: Variations in the influence of Mexican American leaders over the Mexican American population at large account in part for variations in ethnic consciousness.
  E: Variations in rates of Mexican immigration and naturalization account in part for variations in ethnic consciousness.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The passage discusses the Mexican American Generation and their political diversity, and the author's criticisms of a recent study by Mario Garcia.
  The author argues that Garcia may be exaggerating the representativeness of the views of the activists he studies, given demographic changes over time and variations in ethnic consciousness.
  A: There is no evidence in the passage to support this statement.
  B: The passage suggests that an increase in the proportion of Mexican Americans born in the United States might not necessarily result in an increase in political activism or ethnic consciousness.
  C: There is no evidence in the passage to support this statement.
  D: The passage suggests that variations in the influence of Mexican American leaders over the Mexican American population might account for variations in ethnic consciousness.
  E: The passage suggests that variations in rates of Mexican immigration and naturalization might account for variations in ethnic consciousness.
Thought:
  The passage discusses demographic changes over time that may have affected Mexican American political activism and ethnic consciousness, including an increase in the proportion of Mexican Americans born in the United States and changes in patterns of immigration and naturalization.
  The passage also suggests that the political diversity of Mexican Americans during this period might have been influenced by the varying degrees of influence of different groups of activists and leaders.
  Therefore, it is possible that variations in rates of Mexican immigration and naturalization might account in part for variations in ethnic consciousness among Mexican Americans during this period.
  Answer: E
Criticism:
  None
Action: Answer("E")

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 51 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: One of the more striking developments in modem North American dance was African American choreographer Katherine Dunham's introduction of a technique known as dance-isolation, in which one part of the body moves in one rhythm while other parts are kept stationary or are moved in different rhythms. The incorporation of this technique into North American and European choreography is relatively recent, although various forms of the technique have long been essential to traditional dances of certain African, Caribbean, and Pacific-island cultures. Dunham's success in bringing dance-isolation and other traditional techniques from those cultures into the mainstream of modern North American dance is due in no small part to her training in both anthropological research and choreography.As an anthropologist in the 1930s, Dunham was one of the pioneers in the field of dance ethnology. Previously, dance had been neglected as an area of social research, primarily because most social scientists gravitated toward areas likely to be recognized by their peers as befitting scientifically rigorous, and therefore legitimate, modes of inquiry. Moreover, no other social scientist at that time was sufficiently trained in dance to be able to understand dance techniques, while experts in dance were not trained in the methods of social research. Starting in 1935, Dunham conducted a series of research projects into traditional Caribbean dance forms, with special interest in their origins in African culture. Especially critical to her success was her approach to research, which diverged radically from the methodology that prevailed at the time. Colleagues in anthropology advised her not to become too closely involved in the dances she was observing, both because of the extreme physical demands of the dances, and because they subscribed to the long-standing view, now fortunately recognized as unrealistic, that effective data gathering can and must be conducted from a position of complete detachment. But because of her interest and her skill as a performer, she generally eschewed such caution and participated in the dances herself. Through prolonged immersion of this kind, Dunham was able not only to comprehend various dances as complex cultural practices, but also to learn the techniques well enough to teach them to others and incorporate them into new forms of ballet. Between 1937 and 1945, Dunham developed a research-to-performance method that she used to adapt Caribbean dance forms for use in theatrical performance, combining them with modern dance styles she learned in Chicago. The ballets she created in this fashion were among the first North American dances to rectify the exclusion of African American themes from the medium of modern dance. Her work was thus crucial in establishing African American dance as an art form in its own right, making possible future companies such as Arthur Mitchell's Dance Theater of Harlem.
Question: The passage suggests that the author would be most likely to agree with which one of the following statements about the colleagues mentioned in line 33?
Choices:
  A: They were partly correct in recommending that Dunham change her methods of data collection, since injury sustained during fieldwork might have compromised her research.
  B: They were partly correct in advising Dunham to exercise initial caution in participating in the Caribbean dances, since her skill in performing them improved with experience.
  C: They were incorrect in advising Dunham to increase the degree of her detachment, since extensive personal investment in fieldwork generally enhances scientific rigor.
  D: They were incorrect in assuming that researchers in the social sciences are able to gather data in an entirely objective manner.
  E: They were incorrect in assuming that dance could be studied with the same degree of scientific rigor possible in other areas of ethnology.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The author discusses the colleagues in anthropology who advised Dunham not to become too closely involved in the dances she was observing.
Thought:
  Although Dunham's colleagues in anthropology had advised her not to become too closely involved in the dances and to maintain detachment, Dunham participated in the dances herself and was successful in her research and incorporation of dance techniques into new forms of ballet.
  Therefore, the author is likely to disagree with the methodology of complete detachment in social research.
  The author believes that effective data gathering is often enhanced by a degree of personal investment.
  Therefore, the most likely statement the author would agree with is that the colleagues mentioned in line 33 were incorrect in advising Dunham to increase the degree of her detachment, since extensive personal investment in fieldwork generally enhances scientific rigor.
  The answer is C: They were incorrect in advising Dunham to increase the degree of her detachment, since extensive personal investment in fieldwork generally enhances scientific rigor.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The author discusses the advice that colleagues in anthropology gave Katherine Dunham when she was starting her research into traditional Caribbean dance forms.
  The colleagues suggested that Dunham not get too involved in the dances she observed and keep a distance.
  The author describes the long-standing view of some social scientists that conducting research from a position of complete detachment leads to more effective data gathering.
Thought: 
  The author describes how Dunham diverged from the prevailing methodology of social scientists by deeply immersing herself in the dances she was researching and performing them herself.
  The author suggests that this approach was crucial to Dunham's success in understanding the dances as complex cultural practices, learning their techniques, and teaching them to others.
  The author does not suggest that Dunham's method of data collection was less effective or rigorous than the detachment approach recommended by her colleagues.
  Instead, the author suggests that Dunham's method was an innovation that broke new ground in the field of dance ethnology and had a significant impact on the development of modern North American dance.
  The author also implies that the overemphasis on detachment in social research prior to Dunham's work was a limiting factor that prevented dance from being recognized as a legitimate area of social research.
  Therefore, the author would be most likely to disagree with the view that increasing the degree of detachment in ethnographic research enhances scientific rigor.
  The correct answer is C: They were incorrect in advising Dunham to increase the degree of her detachment, since extensive personal investment in fieldwork generally enhances scientific rigor.
Criticism:
  None.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 2:

  Dunham was both an anthropologist and a choreographer, and combined her skills to bring traditional dance techniques from African, Caribbean, and Pacific-island cultures into mainstream modern North American dance.
  Dunham's success was due to her approach to research, which involved participating in the dances she was observing and understanding them as complex cultural practices.

  The colleagues recommended that Dunham not participate in the dances she was observing for fear of physical harm and lack of scientific rigor.
  However, Dunham's success in bringing traditional dance techniques from other cultures into mainstream modern North American dance was due in part to her hands-on approach to research.
  Therefore, the author would most likely disagree with the colleagues' advice to increase the degree of detachment in fieldwork.

  The passage shows that Dunham did become involved and that this immersion helped her create new dance techniques.
  The author suggests that Dunham's approach was successful because traditional methods of social research were not well-suited to studying dance.
  Therefore, the author would most likely agree that the colleagues mentioned in line 33 were incorrect in advising detachment. 
  Choice C reflects this understanding.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 52 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: The Internet makes possible the instaotaoeous transmission and retrieval of digital text. It is widely assumed that this capacity will lead to the displacement of printed books by digitized books that are read mainly on computer screens or handheld electronic devices. But it is more likely, I believe, that most digital files of books will be prioted and bound on demand at point of sale by machines that can quickly and inexpensively make single copies that are indistinguishable from books made in fiIctories. Once most books have been digitized, aoyone with access to the Internet will be able to purchase printed books from a practieally limitless digital catalog that includes even those books that, under traditional publishing assumptions, would have been desigoated "out of print." Also, the digital publication of a book online involves no pbysical inventory', thereby eliminating the costs of warehousing, shipping books to wholesalers and to retail stores, displaying pbysieal books in retail stores, and returning unsold books to publishers. This would make digital publishing much less expensive than traditional publishing. Given the economic efficiency and convenience for customers of this new digital model of publishing, it is likely to eventually supplant or at least rival traditional publishingalthough it will be some time before a catalog of printable digitized books becomes large enough to jusillY investment in book prioting machines at numerous regional sites. Moreover, the elimination of whole categories of expensemeans that under the digital publishing model,authors would be responsible for a greater proportion of the value of the final product and would therefore, according to literal)' agents, be entitled to a larger share of the proceeds. Currently a large percentage of publishers' revenue is absorbed by the costs of printing, selling, and distributing pbysical books, costs that are irrelevant to digital publication. LiteraI)' agents marketing new manuscripts could thus be expected to demand a significantly bigger slice of revenue for their authors than has been traditional. But large, established publishing houses, which are heavily invested in the infrastructure of traditional publishing, initially will be reluctant to accede. So the opportunity to bid for new manuscripts will go first to upstart digital-publishing firms unfettered by traditional practices or infrastructure. Under this competitive pressure, traditional publishers will have to reduee their redundant functions in order to accommodate higher royalty payments to authors or else they will lose their authors. Such adjustments are typical of the interval between a departing economic model and its successor and may help explain the caution with which today's publishing conglomerates are approaching the digital future.
Question: The author uses the phrase "whole categories of expense" (lines 30-31) primarily to refer to
Choices:
  A: the fees collected by literal agents from their clients
  B: the price paid to have books printed and bound
  C: the royalties paid to authors by their publisbers
  D: the costs specific to the retail trade in traditional printed books
  E: the total sales ofa book minus the value of those books returned unsold to the bookseller

  Therefore, the correct answer is D: the costs specific to the retail trade in traditional printed books.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 53 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Passage A Jury nullification occurs when the jury acquits the defendant in a criminal case in disregard of the judge's instructions and contrary to the jury's findings of fact. Sometimes a jury's nullification decision is based on mercy for the defendant, sometimes on dislike for the victim. Juries have also sometimes nullified when the defendant engaged in civil disobedience and the jurors agreed with the actions. While instances of jury nullification are probably few, the problems created by the jury's power to nullify are great. First, we do not know how the power is used. Because juries are not required to and typically do not explain their verdicts, it is impossible to say how often nullification occurs. This means that we also do not know how often juries use this power for evil ends rather than for good ones. Second, juries often have insufficient evidence to make a reasoned nullification decision. Evidence that might inform such a decision, such as a defendant's past brushes with the law, usually is not admitted at trial because it is irrelevant to the technical question of guilt or innocence. Third, jurors are not legislators. We have an elected legislature to pass laws and elected or appointed judges to interpret them. The jury is unelected, is unaccountable, and has no obligation to think through the effect an acquittal will have on others. Reasonable people can disagree on the proper reach of the criminal laws. Nevertheless, the place for them to disagree is in public, where the reasons for revisions of the laws can be scrutinized and debated. Passage B Police and prosecutors have discretion to decide which violations of the law to pursue and which to overlook. Even with such discretion, however, these officials can sometimes be overzealous. In such cases, the jury can act as a safety valve and use its own discretion to decide, for example, that a case is too trivial or the circumstances too extenuating for the case to result in a conviction. When a jury nullifies because it does not believe a law should be applied to a particular defendant, the jury can also be viewed as assisting the legislature. Legislatures create general laws both because they cannot foresee every variation that may arise, and because legislators often have competing views about what should be included in legislation. and.so must settle for broad language if any laws are to be passed. Similarly, when a jury nullifies because it believes a law is unjust, it also performs a useful function vis-a-vis the legislature, namely indicating to the legislature that there may be a problem with the law in question.It may happen that a jury will be persuaded to nullify by factors they should ignore, but such instances of nullification are likely to be uncommon. For a jury to agree to nullify means that the case for nullification must be so compelling that all twelve of the jurors, despite their different backgrounds and perspectives, nevertheless agree that nullification is the appropriate course of action.
Question: The authors of the passages would be most likely to disagree over whether
Choices:
  A: juries should be more forthcoming about the reasoning behind their verdicts
  B: laws are subject to scrutiny and debate by reasonable people
  C: it is likely that elected officials are more biased in their decision making than jurors are
  D: it is within the purview of juries not only to apply the law but to interpret it
  E: police and prosecutors should have less discretion to decide which violations of the law to pursue
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Passage A discusses the issues with jury nullification, including the lack of accountability and the potential for misuse of power.
  Passage B argues that jury nullification can be a useful check on overzealous prosecutors and can also serve as a signal to the legislature that there may be a problem with a particular law.
Thought:
  The authors of Passage A would be more likely to oppose jury nullification due to its potential for abuse and the lack of accountability of jurors.
  The authors of Passage B would be more likely to support jury nullification because it can act as a check on prosecutorial overreach and can signal a problem with a law to the legislature.
  While both passages recognize the potential for jury misuse of power and both acknowledge that laws are subject to scrutiny and debate, the differing opinions on the usefulness of jury nullification suggest that the authors would disagree on whether juries should have the power to nullify in the first place.
  The authors do not address the issue of whether elected officials are more biased in their decision making than jurors are, nor do they directly address the issue of whether juries should be more forthcoming with their reasoning behind their verdicts.
  The authors of Passage B advocate for the use of discretion in the prosecution of minor offenses, but do not take a stance on whether police and prosecutors should have less discretion overall.
  Therefore, the authors of the passages would be most likely to disagree over whether it is within the purview of juries not only to apply the law but to interpret it.
Action: Answer("D")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  Passages A and B both talk about the power of juries to nullify a verdict.
  Passage A mentions problems created by the power of nullification such as lack of accountability and insufficient evidence.
  It also suggests that legislative changes should be made in public and that jurors are not equipped to do this.
  Passage B, on the other hand, sees jury nullification as a safety valve against overzealous prosecutions.
  It suggests that nullification can be a way of indicating to the legislature that a law may be problematic.
Thought: 
  Passage A is critical of jury nullification.
  It believes that juries are ill-suited to the task of revising laws and that their lack of accountability can lead to abuses.
  In contrast, Passage B sees nullification as an important way of ensuring that the law is applied fairly and appropriately.
  It sees juries as a check on overzealous prosecutions and as a way of indicating to the legislature when laws need to be revised.
  Therefore, the authors of the passages would most likely disagree over whether it is within the purview of juries not only to apply the law but to interpret it.
  Passage A would likely argue that juries lack the expertise to interpret the law and that this should be left to judges.
  Passage B would likely argue that juries have the right to interpret the law insofar as it affects a particular defendant, and to indicate to the legislature when the law needs to be revised.
  The authors do not seem to directly disagree on any of the other choices.
Action: Answer("D")

  Therefore, the authors would most likely disagree over whether it is within the purview of juries not only to apply the law but to interpret it.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 54 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: By 1970 it was well established that ultraviolet light from the sun contributes to skin cancer. Fortunately, much of the sun's most damaging ultraviolet radiation is screened out by a thin, diffuse layer of ozone-a toxic form of oxygen-in the stratosphere, 1 0 to 25 miles above the earth's surface. During the 1 970s, however, public policy makers worldwide were alerted to the fragility of the ozone layer through the pioneering research and advocacy of two Nobel Prize-winning scientists, Mario Molina and F. Sherwood Rowland. In the absence of pollutants, stratospheric ozone concentrations should remain stable over time, with natural production and destruction of the gas in rough equilibrium. Molina and Rowland showed how manufactured chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)-highly volatile chemicals, millions of tons of which had been used each year in products such as aerosol sprays and refrigerants-chemically attack and deplete the ozone layer, diminishing its effectiveness as a shield against ultraviolet radiation. Studying two freon gases-types of CFCs-they observed that, when released into the lower atmosphere (troposphere), these gases slowly diffuse upward into the stratosphere. Then??, subjected to massive ultraviolet radiation, they break down into their constituent elements, including chlorine. The resulting increase in the concentration of chlorine in the stratosphere is devastating to the ozone layer. Chlorine and ozone chemically react in a way that both destroys the ozone and regenerates the chlorine atoms. As a result of this chemical reaction, each chlorine atom could destroy as many as 1 00,000 ozone molecules before becoming inactive. In 1 974 the two scientists estimated that the atmosphere contained the accumulation of five years of global CFC production. This meant that, given the rate of diffusion and breakdown of CFCs in the atmosphere, the depletion of the ozone layer would continue for years, if not decades, even if the production and use of CFCs were to cease immediately. Recognizing this as a pressing environmental threat, Molina and Rowland became public advocates for a prompt and proportionate public policy response. As a result, Molina was invited to testify before the U.S. Congress and was later appointed to the U.S. National Science Foundation Committee on Fluorocarbon Technology Assessment. Predictably, the work of Molina and Rowland and their advocacy of dramatic policy changes were subjected to attacks by critics, especially scientists with ties to the CFC industry. However, over time their views were corroborated, especially by the discovery of a hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica, and this led to the development of an international agreement (the Montreal Protocol of 1 987) to ban the production of ozone-depleting gases. In North America, CFCs were banned in the late 1 970s, leading to a transformation in packaging for consumer spray products and the development of more environmentally friendly refrigerant chemicals.
Question: Which one of the following statements is most strongly supported by the information in the passage?
Choices:
  A: No refrigerant chemicals other than CFCs had been discovered when Molina and Rowland suggested that CFC production cease.
  B: Refrigerant chemicals developed as substitutes for CFCs after 1987 release fewer chlorine atoms into the stratosphere than CFCs do.
  C: CFCs were originally used in refrigeration components because they provided the most energy-efficient means of refrigeration
  D: The Montreal Protocol led to the cessation of CFC production in North America.
  E: Some of the refrigerant chemicals being manufactured today contain chemicals known to be environmentally damaging.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) chemically attack and deplete the ozone layer.
  The two scientists who discovered this were Mario Molina and F. Sherwood Rowland.
  CFCs were used in products such as aerosol sprays and refrigerants.
  CFCs are highly volatile and millions of tons of CFCs were used each year.
  CFCs break down into their constituent elements, including chlorine.
  Chlorine and ozone chemically react in a way that both destroys the ozone and regenerates the chlorine atoms.
  The resulting increase in the concentration of chlorine in the stratosphere is devastating to the ozone layer.
  In 1987, the international community signed the Montreal Protocol, banning the production of ozone-depleting gases, including CFCs.
Thought: 
  The passage discusses the negative effects of CFCs on the ozone layer and the advocacy of Molina and Rowland to prompt public policy changes.
  Nothing in the passage suggests that there weren't any other refrigerant chemicals discovered when Molina and Rowland suggested that CFC production cease.
  The passage discusses the development of more environmentally friendly refrigerant chemicals after the cessation of CFC production, but doesn't provide data on the comparative amount of chlorine atoms released by these chemicals.
  The passage doesn't mention that CFCs were used in refrigeration components because they provided the most energy-efficient means of refrigeration.
  The passage does mention explicitly that CFCs were banned in North America in the late 1970s, not as a result of the Montreal Protocol.
  While the passage discusses the development of more environmentally friendly refrigerant chemicals, nothing in the passage suggests that all of them are completely free of chemicals known to be environmentally damaging.
  Based on this, the most strongly supported statement is that "CFCs were banned in North America." which is option D.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("D")

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 55 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Industries that use biotechnology are convinced that intellectual property protection should be allowable for discoveries that stem from research and have commercial potential. Biotechnology researchers in academic institutions increasingly share this view because of their reliance on research funding that is in part conditional on the patentability of their results. However, questions about the extent to which biotechnology patenting is hindering basic research have recently come to the fore, and the patenting and commercialization of biotechnology inventions are now the focus of increased scrutiny by scientists and policy makers. The perceived threat to basic research relates to restrictions on access to research materials, such as genetic sequences, cell lines, and genetically altered animals. These restrictions are seen as arising either from enforcement of a patent right or through operation of a contractual agreement. Some researchers fear that patenting biological materials will result in the patent holder's attempting or threatening to enjoin further research through a legal action for patent infringement. In other instances, a patent holder or the owner of biological materials may refuse to make such materials available to scientists conducting basic research unless a costly materials-transfer agreement or license agreement is undertaken. For example, the holder of a patent on unique biological materials may want to receive a benefit or compensation for the costs invested in the creation of the material. Academic researchers who oppose biotechnology patents fear that corporate patent holders will charge prohibitively high fees for the right to conduct basic research involving the use of patented materials. While it is true that the communal tradition of freely sharing research materials has shifted to a market model, it is also undoubtedly true that even in the early days of biotechnology, some researchers took measures to prevent competitors from gaining access to materials they had created. Scientists who resist the idea of patenting biotechnology seem to be confusing patent rights with control of access to biological materials. They mistakenly assume that granting a patent implies granting the right to deny access. In reality, whether a patent could or would be enforced against a researcher, particularly one conducting basic and noncommercial research, is questionable. First, patent litigation is an expensive endeavor and one usually initiated only to protect a market position occupied by the patent holder or an exclusive patent licensee. Second, there has been a tradition among judges deciding patent cases to respect a completely noncommercial research exception to patent infringement. Moreover, it is likely that patents will actually spur rather than hinder basic research, because patents provide scientists with a compelling incentive to innovate. Researchers know that patents bring economic rewards as well as a degree of licensing control over the use of their discoveries.
Question: With which one of the following statements would the author be most likely to agree?
Choices:
  A: In the early days of biotechnology research,scientists freely shared research materials because they were not entitled to intellectual property protection for their inventions
  B: Corporate patent holders typically charge excessive fees for the right to conduct research involving their patented materials.
  C: The cost of patent litigation is an effective check on patent holders who might otherwise try to prevent researchers engaged in basic research from using patented materials.
  D: Biotechnology researchers in academic institutions rely too heavily on funding that is partially contingent on the patentability of their results.
  E: Scientists who oppose the idea of patenting biotechnology do so because their work is not sufficiently innovative to qualify for patent protection.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage discusses the various opinions regarding the patenting of biotechnology and its impact on basic research.
Thought:
  The author argues against the fear that patents on biological materials will hinder basic research. 
  The author explains that patents provide scientists with incentives to innovate and that there is a non-commercial research exception to patent infringement.
  The author believes that patents will spur rather than hinder basic research.
  Therefore, the author would most likely agree with statement C: The cost of patent litigation is an effective check on patent holders who might otherwise try to prevent researchers engaged in basic research from using patented materials.
Criticism: 
  None.
Action: Answer("C")

  The passage suggests that patent litigation is expensive and typically initiated to protect a market position, and judges may respect a noncommercial research exception to patent infringement.
Thought: 
  The passage argues against the idea that patenting biotechnology hinders basic research, noting that patents spur innovation and providing evidence that patent holders cannot or would not prevent basic research on their inventions. 
  The passage suggests that patent litigation is an effective deterrent against patent holders attempting to prevent noncommercial research on their patented materials.
  Therefore, the author would most likely agree with statement C: "The cost of patent litigation is an effective check on patent holders who might otherwise try to prevent researchers engaged in basic research from using patented materials."

  None apparent.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 56 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: By 1970 it was well established that ultraviolet light from the sun contributes to skin cancer. Fortunately, much of the sun's most damaging ultraviolet radiation is screened out by a thin, diffuse layer of ozone-a toxic form of oxygen-in the stratosphere, 1 0 to 25 miles above the earth's surface. During the 1 970s, however, public policy makers worldwide were alerted to the fragility of the ozone layer through the pioneering research and advocacy of two Nobel Prize-winning scientists, Mario Molina and F. Sherwood Rowland. In the absence of pollutants, stratospheric ozone concentrations should remain stable over time, with natural production and destruction of the gas in rough equilibrium. Molina and Rowland showed how manufactured chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs)-highly volatile chemicals, millions of tons of which had been used each year in products such as aerosol sprays and refrigerants-chemically attack and deplete the ozone layer, diminishing its effectiveness as a shield against ultraviolet radiation. Studying two freon gases-types of CFCs-they observed that, when released into the lower atmosphere (troposphere), these gases slowly diffuse upward into the stratosphere. Then??, subjected to massive ultraviolet radiation, they break down into their constituent elements, including chlorine. The resulting increase in the concentration of chlorine in the stratosphere is devastating to the ozone layer. Chlorine and ozone chemically react in a way that both destroys the ozone and regenerates the chlorine atoms. As a result of this chemical reaction, each chlorine atom could destroy as many as 1 00,000 ozone molecules before becoming inactive. In 1 974 the two scientists estimated that the atmosphere contained the accumulation of five years of global CFC production. This meant that, given the rate of diffusion and breakdown of CFCs in the atmosphere, the depletion of the ozone layer would continue for years, if not decades, even if the production and use of CFCs were to cease immediately. Recognizing this as a pressing environmental threat, Molina and Rowland became public advocates for a prompt and proportionate public policy response. As a result, Molina was invited to testify before the U.S. Congress and was later appointed to the U.S. National Science Foundation Committee on Fluorocarbon Technology Assessment. Predictably, the work of Molina and Rowland and their advocacy of dramatic policy changes were subjected to attacks by critics, especially scientists with ties to the CFC industry. However, over time their views were corroborated, especially by the discovery of a hole in the ozone layer over Antarctica, and this led to the development of an international agreement (the Montreal Protocol of 1 987) to ban the production of ozone-depleting gases. In North America, CFCs were banned in the late 1 970s, leading to a transformation in packaging for consumer spray products and the development of more environmentally friendly refrigerant chemicals.

Choices:
  A: testing to see whether the chemical is capable of reacting with forms of oxygen other than ozone
  B: testing to see whether the chemical,when released into the lower atmosphere, would react with other chemicals commonly found there
  C: testing the chemical to determine whether it would chemically react with chlorine
  D: testing to see what chemical properties the chemical or its constituent elements share with chlorine
  E: testing the chemical to see if it would break down into its components when subjected to ultraviolet radiation

  The best experiment to determine whether a particular chemical could replace CFCs without damaging the ozone layer would be testing the chemical to determine whether it would chemically react with chlorine, which would indirectly suggest if it would cause a depletion of the ozone layer.
  Therefore, the answer is C: testing the chemical to determine whether it would chemically react with chlorine.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Passage A Karl Popper's main contribution to the philosophy of science science concerns the power of negative evidence. The fundamental point is simple: No number of white swans, for example, can ever prove that all swans are white, but a single black swan disproves the hypothesis. Popper gives this logical asymmetry between positive and negative evidence hyperbolic application, maintaining that positive evidence has no value as evidence and that negative evidence is tantamount to disproof. Moreover, Popper takes the search for negative evidence to be at the heart of scientific research; that is, for Popper, scientific research involves not only generating bold theories, but also searching for evidence that would disprove them. Indeed, for him, a theory counts as scientific only if it makes predictions that are testable in this way. However, Popper's use of the logical asymmetry does not adequately capture the actual situation scientists face. If a theory deductively entails a false prediction, then the theory must be false as well. But a scientific theory rarely entails predictions on its own. When scientists actually derive a theory's predictions, they almost always need diverse additional "auxiliary" premises, which appeal to other theories, to the correct functioning of instrumentation, to the absence of disturbing forces, etc. When a prediction fails, logic indicates that at least one of the premises must be false, but it does not indicate which one. When an experiment does not work out as predicted, there is usually more than one possible explanation. Positive evidence is never conclusive. But negative evidence rarely is either. Passage B When the planet Uranus was discovered, astronomers attempted to predict its orbit. They based their predictions on Newton's laws and auxiliary assumptions about the mass of the sun and the masses, orbits, and velocities of other planets. One of the auxiliary assumptions was that no planets existed in the vicinity of Uranus. When the astronomers made their observations, they found that the orbit they had predicted for Uranus was incorrect. One possible explanation for the failure of their prediction was that Newton's laws were incorrect. Another was that there was an error in the auxiliary assumptions. The astronomers changed their assumptions about the existence of other planets, concluding that there must be another planet close enough to Uranus to produce the observed orbit. Not long afterward, scientists discovered the planet Neptune in the precise place it would have to be to bring their calculations into alignment with their observations Later astronomers, again using Newton's laws, predicted the orbit of Mercury. Once again, the predictions were not borne out. They hypothesized the existence of another planet in the vicinity, which they called Vulcan. However, Vulcan was never found, and some scientists began to think that perhaps Newton's laws were in error. Finally, when Einstein's general theory of relativity was introduced, astronomers discovered that calculations based on that theory and the old auxiliary assumptions predicted the observed orbit of Mercury, leading to the rejection of Newton's theory of gravity and to increased confidence in Einstein's theory.
Question: In passage B, which one of the following most clearly illustrates a disturbing force, as described in passage A (line 26)?
Choices:
  A: Uranus
  B: the sun
  C: Neptune
  D: Mercury
  E: the moon
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  Passage A discusses Karl Popper's main contribution to the philosophy of science, and the power of negative evidence.
  Popper believes that negative evidence is at the heart of scientific research, and that scientific research involves generating theories that can be tested.
  Passage B discusses how scientists used their theories to predict the orbits of planets, and how they had to change their auxiliary premises when their predictions failed.
  The passage mentions that one of the auxiliary premises was the absence of disturbing forces.
Thought:
  Passage A mentions that when scientists try to derive a theory's predictions, they almost always need diverse additional "auxiliary" premises, which can include the absence of disturbing forces.
  Passage B discusses how scientists tried to predict the orbits of planets using their theories.
  To predict the orbit of Uranus, they made the auxiliary assumption that no planets existed in the vicinity of Uranus.
  When their predictions failed, they changed their assumption to conclude that there must be another planet close enough to Uranus to produce the observed orbit.
  This implies that there was a disturbing force, which was the gravitational force of the unknown planet.
  Therefore, the most clearly illustrated disturbing force in Passage B is Neptune, since its gravitational force affected the orbit of Uranus by causing it to deviate from the predicted orbit.
Action: Answer("C")
Response 1:

  Passage B discusses the discovery of Uranus and the subsequent hypothesis of Neptune and Vulcan.
  Disturbing forces are mentioned in passage A and are described as potential source of error.
Thought:
  Passage A states that auxiliary premises may include the absence of disturbing forces.
  Passage B discusses incorrect predictions about the orbit of Uranus.
  Auxiliary premises were used to make calculations about Uranus's orbit.
  They made assumptions that other planets do not exist which is an auxiliary premise.
  Another assumption is that there is no disturbing force.
  From the passage B, the existence of Neptune was predicted, which was due to some disturbing force.
  Hence, Neptune is the answer.

  A theory counts as scientific only if it makes predictions that are testable.
  When scientists actually derive a theory's predictions, they almost always need diverse additional "auxiliary" premises.
  When an experiment does not work out as predicted, there is usually more than one possible explanation.

  The answer is E: the moon.

  The moon's gravitational force is often excluded from predictions of the orbit of Mercury because it is too weak. However, this force can disrupt calculations of Mercury's orbit at very high degrees of precision.

### Temperature: 10.0 | Problem 58 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: The Internet makes possible the instaotaoeous transmission and retrieval of digital text. It is widely assumed that this capacity will lead to the displacement of printed books by digitized books that are read mainly on computer screens or handheld electronic devices. But it is more likely, I believe, that most digital files of books will be prioted and bound on demand at point of sale by machines that can quickly and inexpensively make single copies that are indistinguishable from books made in fiIctories. Once most books have been digitized, aoyone with access to the Internet will be able to purchase printed books from a practieally limitless digital catalog that includes even those books that, under traditional publishing assumptions, would have been desigoated "out of print." Also, the digital publication of a book online involves no pbysical inventory', thereby eliminating the costs of warehousing, shipping books to wholesalers and to retail stores, displaying pbysieal books in retail stores, and returning unsold books to publishers. This would make digital publishing much less expensive than traditional publishing. Given the economic efficiency and convenience for customers of this new digital model of publishing, it is likely to eventually supplant or at least rival traditional publishingalthough it will be some time before a catalog of printable digitized books becomes large enough to jusillY investment in book prioting machines at numerous regional sites. Moreover, the elimination of whole categories of expensemeans that under the digital publishing model,authors would be responsible for a greater proportion of the value of the final product and would therefore, according to literal)' agents, be entitled to a larger share of the proceeds. Currently a large percentage of publishers' revenue is absorbed by the costs of printing, selling, and distributing pbysical books, costs that are irrelevant to digital publication. LiteraI)' agents marketing new manuscripts could thus be expected to demand a significantly bigger slice of revenue for their authors than has been traditional. But large, established publishing houses, which are heavily invested in the infrastructure of traditional publishing, initially will be reluctant to accede. So the opportunity to bid for new manuscripts will go first to upstart digital-publishing firms unfettered by traditional practices or infrastructure. Under this competitive pressure, traditional publishers will have to reduee their redundant functions in order to accommodate higher royalty payments to authors or else they will lose their authors. Such adjustments are typical of the interval between a departing economic model and its successor and may help explain the caution with which today's publishing conglomerates are approaching the digital future.
Question: It can most reasonably be inferred that the aulbor would agree wilb which one oflbe following statements?
Choices:
  A: Those publishers that fail to embrace the new digital model ofpub1ishing will be uuiikely to remain economically competitive.
  B: The primary threat to the spread of digital publishing will be the widespread use of computers aud haudheld devices for reading text.
  C: The growth of digital publishing is likely to revitalize the book retail business.
  D: Any book will sell more copies ifit is published digitally thau if it is published traditionally.
  E: Digital publishing will allow publishers to substantially decrease the amount of money they allocate for advertising their books.
Response 0:

  The author believes that digitized books will not necessarily lead to the displacement of printed books. 
  The author believes that most digital files of books will be printed and bound on demand at point of sale. 
  The author believes that once most books have been digitized, anyone with access to the Internet will be able to purchase printed books from a practically limitless digital catalog that includes even those books that, under traditional publishing assumptions, would have been designated "out of print."
  The author believes that digital publishing would be much less expensive than traditional publishing, due to the elimination of whole categories of expense such as warehousing, shipping books to wholesalers and retail stores, and displaying physical books in retail stores.  
  The author believes that under the digital publishing model, authors would be responsible for a greater proportion of the value of the final product.  
Thought: 
  Based on the author's beliefs, it can be inferred that traditional publishers who do not embrace the new digital model of publishing will be unlikely to remain economically competitive.
  Therefore, the answer is A: Those publishers that fail to embrace the new digital model of publishing will be unlikely to remain economically competitive.
Criticism:

The author only suggests that they will have to reduce their redundant functions in order to accommodate higher royalty payments to authors or else they will lose their authors. 
  Therefore, the answer could also be interpreted as D: Any book will sell more copies if it is published digitally than if it is published traditionally.
Action: Answer("D")
